body.p: Juliana Bertazzo is a Teaching Fellow at the Latin American Centre, St. Anthony’s College, University of Oxford. She is also an associate at the LSE - Ideas (Latin America Programme) and an associate fellow at the Institute for the Study of the Americas, in London. Dr Bertazzo has a PhD and a Master’s degree from the University of Campinas and received postgraduate training at the National Defense University (Washington, D.C.).

Sue Branford is a journalist and writer on Latin America, particularly Brazil. She is currently also Visiting Lecturer in Journalism at City University, in London. She has been foreign correspondent in Brazil for several UK newspapers, including the Financial Times and the Guardian. She has published four books, including Cutting the Wire – the Story of the Landless Movement in Brazil (which she co-authored with Jan Rocha) and Politics Transformed - Lula and the Workers Party in Brazil (which she co-authored with Bernardo Kucinski).

Mahruhk Doctor is Lecturer in Political Economy at the University of Hull and Adjunct Professor of Latin American Studies at the Johns Hopkins University (SAIS) Bologna Center in Italy. She is also a Research Associate with the Brazilian Studies Programme, University of Oxford. Her main research interests include development, industrial, trade and infrastructure investment policies in Latin America (with a special focus on Brazil). Her main theoretical and analytical interests lie in (neo-)corporatism, policy network analysis, varieties of capitalism and neo-structuralism. She received her doctorate from the University of Oxford in 2000.

Par Engstrom (BA UCL, MSc London, DPhil Oxford) is Lecturer at the Institute of the Americas, University College London, University of London. He is also co-chair of the London Transitional Justice Network. His current research interests focus on regional human rights institutions, both comparatively and with a particular reference to the Inter-American human rights system. Further research interests include the relationship between human rights and democratization; judicialization of politics; transitional justice; the international relations of the Americas; human rights, humanitarianism, and foreign policy; theories of international relations, particularly relating to international law and institutions; and interdisciplinary approaches to the study of human rights. Recent publications include: “From Amnesty to Accountability: The Ebb and Flow in the Search for Justice in Argentina”, in Leigh A. Payne and Francesca Lessa (eds.), Amnesty in the Age of Human Rights Accountability: Comparative and International Perspectives (forthcoming 2012); co-editor, Critical Perspectives in Transitional Justice, Oxford Transitional Justice Research (forthcoming 2011); “Brasil: los derechos humanos en la política exterior de una potencia emergente”, in Ana Covarrubias and Natalia Saltalamacchia (eds.), Los derechos humanos y la política exterior de los países de América Latina (2011); “Human Rights: Effectiveness of International and Regional Mechanisms” in The International Studies Encyclopedia (2010); and “Why the Human Rights Regime in the Americas Matters”, in Monica Serrano and Ramesh Thakur (eds.), Human Rights Regimes in the Americas (2010).

Anthony Hall is Professor of Social Policy at the London School of Economics and Political Science. He has carried out extensive research and consultancy in the Brazilian Amazon on issues of deforestation, sustainable development and emerging REDD+ activities. He has also written on the impacts of the Bolsa Familia conditional cash transfer programme. His most recent books dealing with Brazil are: Global Impact, Local Action: New Environmental Policy in Latin America (2005) and Forests and Climate Change: The Social Dimensions of REDD in Latin America, which will be published by Edward Elgar in 2012.

Paul Heritage is Professor of Drama and Performance at Queen Mary, University of London and Artistic Director of People’s Palace Projects (www.peoplespalaceprojects.org.uk). He directed theatre-based human rights projects for 15 years, in prisons across Brazil. As a producer he has brought a range of Brazilian companies to major cultural institutions in the UK, including Grupo Galpão at Shakespeare’s Globe Theatre, Grupo Piollin at the Barbican, AfroReggae at the Barbican and Southbank Centre, Nós do Morro at the Royal Shakespeare Company, etc. He has directed Shakespeare in some of Rio de Janeiro’s most distinguished theatres as well as on the borderlands of conflict in the favelas of Vigário Geral, Parada de Lucas, Rocinha, etc. Heritage was a conselheiro (advisor) to the Cultura Viva programme at the Ministry of Culture 2009-2010 and is currently working in partnership with the Secretary of Citizenship and Diversity to create an international programme of cultural exchange for artists and policy makers. In 2004, he was made a Knight of the Order of Rio Branco by the Brazilian government.
Devereaux Kennedy is a Professor of Sociology at Grand Valley State University where he teaches Social Theory. His most recent publication is "Modern Industrial Society: Requiem for a Concept."

Fiona Macaulay is Senior Lecturer in Development Studies in the Division of Peace Studies, University of Bradford, and is a former Research Fellow at the Centre for Brazilian Studies, University of Oxford, and Brazil researcher for Amnesty International. Her research and published work focus on gender, in relation to public policy and party politics, and on criminal justice sector reform (courts, police and prisons) and human rights, in Latin America, especially Brazil. She is the author of Gender Politics in Brazil and Chile (2006) and co-editor of the Journal of Latin American Studies.

Carolina Matos is currently a Lecturer in the Department of Government, University of Essex. She is a journalist, and a former Fellow in Political Communications at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE). She obtained her PhD in Media and Communications at Goldsmiths College in January 2007 with no corrections. Matos has taught and researched in the UK in international journalism, cultural studies, political communications, media and development and Brazilian media and politics at the University of East London (UEL), St. Mary’s College at Twickenham, Goldsmiths and the LSE. As a journalist and academic, Matos worked as a full-time journalist in Brazil for mainstream newspapers and international agencies in the areas of politics, international affairs and culture including Reuters, Unesco, Folha de Sao Paulo, Tribuna da Imprensa and Globo.com. Matos is the author of Journalism and Political Democracy in Brazil (Lexington Books, 2008, 2009) and Media and Politics in Latin America: Globalization, democracy and identity (IB Tauris, 2012) as well as newspaper and journal articles.

Lecio Morais is a specialist in public sector budgeting and planning. Morais has a degree in Economics and a Master’s degree in Political Science, and is currently working as a technical advisor to the leadership of the Communist Party of Brazil (PCdoB) at the Chamber of Deputies in Brasilia, Brazil. He has published several book chapters and journal articles, and a piece he co-authored with Alfredo Saad Filho, titled Brazil beyond Lula : Forging Ahead or Pausing for Breath? in Latin American Perspectives 38(31), 2011.

Anthony W. Pereira is a Professor of Brazilian Studies and Director of the Brazil Institute at King’s College London. He obtained his B.A. from Sussex University (U.K.) in 1982 and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Harvard University in 1986 and 1991 respectively. He has held positions at the New School, Tufts, Tulane, and the University of East Anglia. His research interests include the issues of democracy, human rights, and military rule, particularly in Brazil and the southern cone of Latin America. His book Ditadura e Repressão (Dictatorship and Repression) was published in Brazil by Paz e Terra in 2010.

Alfredo Saad-Filho is Professor of Political Economy at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London, UK. He has degrees in Economics from the Universities of Brasilia (Brazil) and London (School of Oriental and African Studies), and has taught and researched in universities in Brazil and Mozambique, as well as in the UK. His research interests include neoliberalism, the political economy of development, industrial policy, Latin American political and economic development, inflation and stabilisation, and the labour theory of value and its applications.

Andrew Stevens is an Assistant Professor in the Faculty of Business Administration at the University of Regina, Canada. His research focuses on the global division of call center employment, trade union organizing, labor studies, and industrial relations.
